name: Sable Antelope
description: This robust antelope belongs to the horse antelope group. It has long, sharp, curved horns (slightly shorter and thinner in females than males) that can reach up to 1.6 m. Adult males are nearly black (‘sable’), with a steep forehead, usually white belly and muzzle, and a contrasting facial pattern. Calves are born beige.
spread_note: Southern and eastern Africa, from eastern Kenya to South Africa
image_alt: Sable antelope, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 1.9–2.5 m; tail length 40–75 cm; shoulder height 115–140 cm; weight 150–270 kg
attractions: The core of their social structure is small groups of adult females centered around a dominant male. Males defend their territory, marking it and attracting females. Mating seasons vary by population to align births with peak food abundance. Newborn calves lie motionless in tall grass for their first days to avoid predators, with the mother staying nearby to watch over them for the first week.
projects_note: The H. niger variani subspecies is considered endangered due to habitat loss, while other subspecies are classified as least concern.
breeding: Prague Zoo has kept sable antelopes since 1970, when a trio arrived directly from the wild. The first calf was born the following year, and by 2014, a total of 113 had been born.
